story: Created with Sketch.'Hell is other people,' as Jean-Paul Satre&nbspobservedClick to followThe Independent OnlineCommuters queuing for Victoria line trains at Green Park Tube stationCommuting in the British capital can be a living nightmare.As we saw during the recent summer heatwave, when temperatures on the London Underground surpassed that at which it’s&nbsplegal&nbspto transport cattle, the Tube can be a particularly gruelling experience.Packed in and shoved up against your fellow passengers on busy rush hour trains, sweat gushing from your armpits as you stare&nbspdown the barrel of another&nbspfull working week in which your&nbspgenius will once again go unappreciated by the philistines of middle-management, dreaming of escape to sunnier&nbspclimes and a new life by the sea... Sorry, where was I?The intensity of the situation can inspire a frustration with one’s fellow humans like few others.The uncomfortable heat exacerbated by someone else's thoughtlessness, exasperating ticks&nbspor selfish lack of consideration for those around them&nbspcan turn even the most mild-mannered nebbish into Genghis Khan.But there’s plenty we can do to make conditions more bearable for one another. If everyone followed the handful of simple, common sense&nbsprules below, commuting on the Tube might be a great deal less toxic.There are two major sources of annoyance at the barriers: the first is people arriving at the front of the queue and only then searching through their pockets or bag for their ticket, card or phone while those standing&nbspbehind smoulder with rage. Folks, just pay attention and be prepared.The other is people who stop dead in their tracks immediately after passing through to consult a map or check Twitter. Do. Not. Do. This.When riding down to platform level, remember to keep moving if you’re taking the left-hand lane.As with the ticket barriers, tourists unfamiliar with the local customs can be partially excused for not knowing good form.&nbspBut on the escalators, you can see clearly in front of you what the natives are doing so there’s really no excuse for not following suit.You wouldn’t stick cautiously at 30mph on the M1, would you?When your train arrives, the correct procedure is to stand aside and queue at either door to let exiting passengers off first, therein creating much-needed space.Everyone should know this – public service announcements telling you precisely what to do resound at every single station -&nbspand yet there’s always&nbspsomeone who takes it as an invitation to violate the implicit social contract and shoulder-barge their way through the wall of would-be departees, causing havoc.As Seinfeld’s George Costanza once screamed at a fellow traveller: “You know we’re living in a society!”Not moving down inside the carriage is probably the biggest frustration for Tube drivers, who are forced to repeat the request again and again over the tannoy at every station they approach. Come on people, what’s so bad about standing in the centre of the aisle and holding a handrail anyway? You often end up with more space.But there are plenty of other habits commonly engaged in, often utterly obliviously, by members of the public that conjure deep-rooted primal fury.Please, please avoid the following. We’re begging you.No loud music hissing from headphones. Come on mate. Not everyone likes Coldplay.No public displays of affection. Guys, please. Your love is grotesque.Don’t talk to strangers. Nobody wants to be bothered on the Tube and your chat-up lines are definitely coming across 90 per cent creepier than you imagine. You’re not John Hamm.No wheelie suitcases&nbspor bulky golf bags at rush hour if you can possibly help it. This might not always be possible to avoid but be realistic.No obnoxious manspreading or taking up a second seat with the aforesaid&nbspunwieldy bag.Food is just about acceptable, just,&nbspso long as it doesn’t have a powerful odour or drip sauce everywhere. Every right-thinking person adores a donner&nbspkebab, but&nbspplease, control yourself.This is perhaps the most contentious and complex of all issues posed by the London Underground: when to give up your seat, which is unquestionably a pleasure to be savoured when it's fair to do so.Everyone fears disappearing into a spiral of shame and&nbspself-loathing if they look up to see fellow travellers glaring at them for not standing to make way for an expectant mother or frail senior. Equally, they don’t want to appear patronising and inadvertently cause offence as a result of misdirected gallantry.UK news in picturesStudents react as they receive their 'A' level results at Stoke Newington School and Sixth Form in London. That is why my trade union, Community, is backing&nbspThe Independent’s Final Say&nbspcampaign, to secure a people’s vote on the final deal.”Contribute to the march of a generationAt the last People’s Vote March in June, well over 100,000 people marched on parliament.Community’s roots are in textile manufacturing and the steel industry – pushed to the brink of collapse in recent years as much larger economies such as China distort international markets.In 2018 the industry has faced new pressure in particular from steel tariffs imposed by Donald Trump’s US administration, which Brexiteers title: ilhan omar wins minnesota democratic primary victory speech watch
story: Created with Sketch.'In my last race, I talked about what my win would have meant for that eight-year-old girl in that refugee camp,' she tells crowdClick to followThe Independent USIlhan Omar, who is likely to become the first Somali-American elected to US Congress, made history on Tuesday by winning a seat in Minnesota’s 5th Congressional District.The politician garnered national attention just two years ago after becoming the first Somali American elected to a state legislature in Minnesota - unseating a 22-term Democratic incumbent.In my last race, I talked about what my win would have meant for that eight-year-old girl in that refugee camp,” she told a crowd of supporters after her win.&nbspJahana Hayes could be Connecticut's first black Democrat in CongressTransgender candidate Christine Hallquist makes history in VermontAlexandria Ocasio-Cortez supports Kaniela Ing in Hawaii primaries“And today, today, I still think about her and I think about the kind of hope and optimism all of those eight-year-olds around the country and around the world get from seeing your beautiful faces elect and believe in someone like me.“So I humbly thank you. I congratulate you and I ask you, lets continue to celebrate and bring our joy and hope to the campaign trail tomorrow.”Ms Omar’s family fled Somalia when she was just eight years old as civil war ripped apart the country. They spent four years in a camp in Mombasa, Kenya, with tens of thousands of other refugees.&nbspThe 36-year-old, who is the youngest of seven children, and her family emigrated to America when she was 12 years old. They settled in Minneapolis where she&nbsplearnt English by watching American TV.The mother-of-three also referenced her eight-year-old self when becoming the first Somali-American lawmaker in the US in 2016.This really was a victory for that eight-year-old in that refugee camp, she said. This was a victory for the young woman being forced into child marriage. This was a victory for every person that's been told they have limits on their dreams.Minnesota is home to the biggest population of Somalis outside Somalia and Minneapolis has a neighbourhood nicknamed “Little Mogadishu.”&nbspMs Omar won in Minneapolis and surrounding suburbs – a famously left-leaning district. Her primary victory is expected to lead to a win in the November midterm elections and take her to Congress. She will face Republican candidate Jennifer Zeilinski at the election.&nbspTonight, we are celebrating because we engaged and empowered our community and we won, Ms Omar said in a statement.Our campaign staff, our volunteers, and the people of the Fifth Congressional District are the inspiration we need to get up every day and fight for a democracy that guarantees a more just and equitable society.Ms Omar and Rashida Tlaib - a Palestinian American who won a Detroit-area Democratic primary in Michigan last week and is running unopposed in November - are now in the position to become the first two Muslim women to serve in Congress.I can't wait to walk onto the floor of United States Congress hand in hand with you. So incredibly proud of you.” Ms Tlaib tweeted.A record number of Muslims - at least 90 – have run for political office in the 2018 midterm elections.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.Russian president expresses hope leaders will discuss 'bilateral relations and important matters'Click to followThe Independent OnlineVladimir Putin ready to meet Kim Jong-un to discuss 'urgent issues', says North Korean state mediaThe Russian&nbsppresident congratulated Mr Kim in a telegram to mark&nbspNorth Korea’s national liberation day,&nbspwhich commemorates&nbspthe end of the Second World War and the north’s liberation from Japanese colonial rule, the KCNA news agency reported.“I affirm that I am ready to meet you at an early date to discuss urgent issues of bilateral relations and important matters of the region,” Mr Putin said in the message, without offering a specific date.North and South Korean leaders announce Pyongyang summitNorth Korea hits out at US sanctions and demands to denucleariseNorth Korea has not stopped nuclear weapons programme, UN saysTrump thanks Kim Jong-un for ‘nice letter’ and ‘kind actions’He also expressed hope&nbspthe countries would “continue to develop cooperation for mutual benefits including the realisation of the tripartite project” which would also involve South Korea.Speaking to journalists on Wednesday, the Kremlin’s spokesman, Dmitry&nbspPeskov, confirmed Mr Putin had sent the telegram in which he “stressed his desire and readiness to establish a dialogue,” Channel NewsAsia reported.In June, Mr Putin invited Mr Kim and South Korea’s president, Moon Jae-in, to an economic forum due to take place in Vlaostok next month. It is unclear whether the North Korean leader responded.When Mr Peskov was asked whether the two leaders could meet in Vlaostok, he said the economic forum is&nbsp”open for all the leaders of the region” but said Moscow has “so far” received no confirmation&nbspfrom Pyongyang to indicate Mr Kim&nbspwill attend.Mr Kim also sent a message to Mr Putin, KCNA reported, noting the “valuable tradition” as they “struggled shoulder to shoulder against the common enemy in the arduous anti-Japanese war”, which it said provided the “strong roots” for their diplomatic relations.It was unclear if the message came before or after Mr Putin’s invitation.It comes as North Korea marked its liberation from Japanese rule&nbspwith relatively low-key celebrations.A group of war veterans from the former Soviet Union participated and thousands of people cheered their football team to victory over a South Korean squad in the opening match of an under-15 youth tournament in Pyongyang, which featured players from several countries.People also streamed to statues of the country’s leaders or other monuments to observe the anniversary, as is customary.Escape from North KoreaA hat belonging to Jeong Min-woo in Seoul. Min-woo is from Hyesan, on the border with China. He was a commissioned officer in the Korean People's Army, and left in his uniform. South Korean intelligence confiscated it, but he persuaded his North Korean military contacts to send him a new one.Jeong Min-woo, 29, poses for a photograph in SeoulKang, 28, who wanted to be identified only by her surname, poses for a photograph in Seoul. The parents of Kang sent out a coat across the Chinese border after she reached the South in 2010. I didn't ask my mother to send me this coat, said Kang. But she knew I feel the cold easily and sent it to me. She sent some honey too, but it went missing on the way. The coat is made of dog fur. I don't know what kind of dog. In 2010, it cost about 700,000 North Korean won ($88 at the unofficial rate). It was really expensive. A North Korean friend went to China to pick it up for me. I liked this coat when I got it. I thought my mother must've spent quite a lot of money on it.  The dog fur coat belonging to Kang, My father was a party officer. Our family had a car and we lived in a special apartment. Ordinary people couldn't afford to wear this kind of coat, not even soldiers. Commissioned officers could afford them. Border guards would wear them. It wasn't easy to buy this kind of coat, but as time went on, fake ones began to appear. The state often clamped down on this item. It's technically military supplies so the state monitored people who altered the design of the coat. I know just from looking at this coat that it's a counterfeit one, not the official version. The counterfeit ones look quite different from the original ones. Military officials preferred the fakes to the original because the design looked much better. The children of rich families would wear them. I look too chubby in this, so don't wear it here. I thought I could probably wear it if I altered it.Lee Oui-ryuk is from Onsong, near the border with China. He defected in 2010, and brought his ID card with him. I brought my ID with me when I left North Korea. Juche 95.11.7 (the date in the North Korean calendar, which equates to Nov. 7, 2006) is the date I was issued with my ID. It says here my blood type is A, but I'm actually an O. For the 23 years I lived in North Korea, I thought my blood type was A. They wrote down my blood type without even doing a test. They just wrote whatever they wanted to. I was caught trying to defect to South Korea around Kim Jong Il's birthday. They strengthen border security just before and after that date.The bottom of the lamp is dark, as the saying goes, and I thought I'd be able to cross right under their noses. The soldiers shot at me as I tried to run away from the Tumen River. I managed to get away and hid, but someone reported me and I was caught. That's when I was taken to the bowibu (North Korean secret police) for three months of interrogation. The state ruled that I had tried to defect to South Korea, and I was sent to a camp for political prisoners. I escaped when they were transferring me to the camp. I hid and managed to make it to my big sister's house - that's when I grabbed these photos. I couldn't go home easily, so decided I had to hide in the mountains or somewhere remote. I needed my ID to move around without getting caught. and I took these 12 photos with me in case I wanted to look back and reminisce. I wrote on the back of them so as not to forget.Ji Sung-ho, 35, from Hoeryong, near the border with China. He left North Korea in 2006 with a pair of wooden crutches. I lived as a child beggar in North Korea. I was stealing coals from a train when I fell off and lost my leg and my hand. I had to bring the crutches with me. If I didn't have them, I wouldn't have made it here. The state doesn't help you in North Korea, and people who need crutches make their own. Mine are therefore not factory-made, so they're not perfect and break easily. I had several pairs of crutches but they all broke, and this was the last pair. I used these crutches for 10 years, until I was 25, when I arrived in South Korea. I would steal coal from moving trains and fall off, destroying my crutches. Or I would get beaten up by the police and they'd take and then break my crutches. When they broke, I would make new ones. When I had new ones, I could go back outside.When I first arrived in South Korea I thought about throwing them out. South Korea's intelligence agency gave me a prosthetic leg. My friends said I should throw the crutches out and not think about North Korea. They said I should show Kim Jong Il I was living a new life in South Korea and throw out everything I had from the North. Some asked if I got upset when I saw my crutches. But I couldn't just throw them out. To make my crutches, my friends had given me some wood that they had bought, and someone I knew in North Korea who had carpentry skills had made them. It was my father who added the final touches. There is a lot of love from my North Korean friends and family in these crutches. So I didn't throw them out. The South Korean government gave me some new crutches because the wood from my North Korean ones is hard and painful. But I still keep them, so as not to forget those memories. Kim Ryen Hui, 48, is from Pyongyang. She says she never wanted to defect. In 2011, she says, a broker helped her go to China for treatment on her liver. But the broker tricked her, she said, and she ended up in South Korea. She is campaigning to return, which Seoul says would be against the law. I miss my parents even more than I miss my daughter. They're everything to me. For the first few years, I couldn't even breathe properly when I thought of them. My little brother lives with them in Pyongyang now. My mother can't see out of one eye. The thing I fear the most is finding out they've passed away before I have the chance to go back. My daughter and I have been writing letters and sending photos to each other. My cousin lives in China, so she's been sending them on. My daughter's name is Ri Ryon Gum. She was born on February 15, 1993. I don't want her to live out her life with me here. When she was young, she did taekwondo. She wanted to get involved in espionage operations against South Korea. She was so fearless. That's why she was doing taekwondo - to get involved in anti-South espionage. So I was really surprised to hear she became a chef. In a video of her I received, she explained why. She said that after I had left, she moved in with her father in Pyongyang and had been cooking for him. She said she decided to become a chef so she could fulfill my role at home. I was sad when I heard that.Lee Min-bok, 60, was a researcher at North Korea's Academy of Agricultural Science. He first tried to defect, unsuccessfully, in 1990. He eventually left North Korea in June 1991 and came to South Korea in 1995. His family sent him these diaries. I have a bit of an academic side. According to Kim Il Sung's teachings, people are supposed to keep diaries. Everyone in North Korea should strictly follow Kim Il Sung's teachings, so I did as I was supposed to and kept a diary. Even though Kim Il Sung is a villain here, in North Korea he's above everything. We learned that he studied well and gave our lives purpose. I lived according to those teachings. I wrote these out of loyalty to the Leader. That was our ideology, and I lived my life in strict adherence to it. No one could think differently.I got hold of these diaries 10 years after I arrived in South Korea. I had been sending money to my family in the North and they sent them to me. I didn't write any complaints in diaries. I would've been in big trouble if I did. My diaries are a record of my history in North Korea. I am thinking about turning these diaries into a book. I'd like to publish a book about how to change North Koreans' thinking when unification happens. These diaries show how North Koreans think and how their minds are constructed. People need to make these into a textbook, because they need proof. Talking is not as effective.Song Byeok was a propaganda artist. His father drowned trying to cross the Tumen river, in 2000. When the artist finally left North Korea in 2001, he brought photos of his family with him. We left that August to find food, Byeok recalled, describing the first attempt. We were from a town further inland, and we weren't sure where the river was high and where it was low. I didn't know at the time but the river was swollen because of the rainy season. I thought we had to cross it anyway. All I could think about was getting to China to buy food. I took off my clothes and tied them into a rope to strap us together. I told my father not to let go. As we approached the middle of the river, the strap felt lighter. I looked back and saw my father drifting away. I was devastated.He was going under the water and couldn't get out. I rushed up to the (North Korean) border guards and asked them to save him but they just said why did I come out, why didn't I die too. They handcuffed me and took me away. It was Aug. 28. I was tortured by the bowibu (North Korean secret police) in Hoeryong, then jailed for four months in Chongjin prison camp. But after I was released from the camp I felt like I needed to survive and carry on living. Right before I tried to defect again, I went back home and grabbed my family photos. Even if I died trying, I thought, at least I would have this picture with me. I never found my father. After I came to South Korea, I went back to China in 2004 and held a memorial service for him by the river. My heart still aches.Baek Hwa-sung, 33, left Sinuiju, on the border with China, in 2003 and resettled in South Korea in 2008. He kept a diary as he defected. In 2004, I started to write down all my thoughts in a diary. I didn't know if I'd get caught. I just wanted to let it be known where I was from, and where I wanted to go. After I left the North, I became very depressed, hiding in the mountains alone for a while. The people who were watching over me told me not to come down to the village and left me by myself in a mountain shelter. Alone, with no one to engage with or talk to, I felt like I would go insane. So I wanted to leave something behind in case I died there or got caught - that's why I started to write.Alone in the mountains, I desperately sought something to talk to. That was my diary. My diaries are proof of my life's journey. I read them when I want to remember home. I can't return home, and I already have no memories of my hometown. But when I go through my diaries, there are notes which detail the vivid memories of that time. Sometimes I might forget my father's birthday, but when I go back to my diary, his birthday and my mother's birthday are there. My diaries are a record of my life. When she was young, she did taekwondo. She wanted to get involved in espionage operations against South Korea. She was so fearless. That's why she was doing taekwondo - to get involved in anti-South espionage. So I was really surprised to hear she became a chef. In a video of her I received, she explained why. She said that after I had left, she moved in with her father in Pyongyang and had been cooking for him. She said she decided to become a chef so she could fulfill my role at home. I was sad when I heard that.Lee Min-bok, 60, was a researcher at North Korea's Academy of Agricultural Science. He first tried to defect, unsuccessfully, in 1990. He eventually left North Korea in June 1991 and came to South Korea in 1995. His family sent him these diaries. I have a bit of an academic side. According to Kim Il Sung's teachings, people are supposed to keep diaries. Everyone in North Korea should strictly follow Kim Il Sung's teachings, so I did as I was supposed to and kept a diary. Even though Kim Il Sung is a villain here, in North Korea he's above everything. We learned that he studied well and gave our lives purpose. I lived according to those teachings. I wrote these out of loyalty to the Leader. That was our ideology, and I lived my life in strict adherence to it. No one could think differently.I got hold of these diaries 10 years after I arrived in South Korea. I had been sending money to my family in the North and they sent them to me. I didn't write any complaints in diaries. I would've been in big trouble if I did. My diaries are a record of my history in North Korea. I am thinking about turning these diaries into a book. I'd like to publish a book about how to change North Koreans' thinking when unification happens. These diaries show how North Koreans think and how their minds are constructed. People need to make these into a textbook, because they need proof. Talking is not as effective.Song Byeok was a propaganda artist. His father drowned trying to cross the Tumen river, in 2000. When the artist finally left North Korea in 2001, he brought photos of his family with him. We left that August to find food, Byeok recalled, describing the first attempt. We were from a town further inland, and we weren't sure where the river was high and where it was low. I didn't know at the time but the river was swollen because of the rainy season. I thought we had to cross it anyway. All I could think about was getting to China to buy food. I took off my clothes and tied them into a rope to strap us together. I told my father not to let go. As we approached the middle of the river, the strap felt lighter. I looked back and saw my father drifting away. I was devastated.He was going under the water and couldn't get out. I rushed up to the (North Korean) border guards and asked them to save him but they just said why did I come out, why didn't I die too. They handcuffed me and took me away. It was Aug. 28. I was tortured by the bowibu (North Korean secret police) in Hoeryong, then jailed for four months in Chongjin prison camp. But after I was released from the camp I felt like I needed to survive and carry on living. Right before I tried to defect again, I went back home and grabbed my family photos. Even if I died trying, I thought, at least I would have this picture with me. I never found my father. After I came to South Korea, I went back to China in 2004 and held a memorial service for him by the river. My heart still aches.Baek Hwa-sung, 33, left Sinuiju, on the border with China, in 2003 and resettled in South Korea in 2008. He kept a diary as he defected. In 2004, I started to write down all my thoughts in a diary. I didn't know if I'd get caught. I just wanted to let it be known where I was from, and where I wanted to go. After I left the North, I became very depressed, hiding in the mountains alone for a while. The people who were watching over me told me not to come down to the village and left me by myself in a mountain shelter. Alone, with no one to engage with or talk to, I felt like I would go insane. So I wanted to leave something behind in case I died there or got caught - that's why I started to write.Alone in the mountains, I desperately sought something to talk to. That was my diary. My diaries are proof of my life's journey. I read them when I want to remember home. I can't return home, and I already have no memories of my hometown. But when I go through my diaries, there are notes which detail the vivid memories of that time. Sometimes I might forget my father's birthday, but when I go back to my diary, his birthday and my mother's birthday are there. My diaries are a record of my life. They prove I'm alive.North Korea has been preparing for an extravagant celebration for its national foundation day on 9 September.The festivities are intended to be a spectacular homage to Mr Kim’s campaign to bolster his country’s image abroad and ease tensions on the Korean Peninsula through diplomacy with its neighbours and the US.Diplomacy with China and Russia appears to be progressing, with reports Chinese tourism to North Korea is already on the rise.But it remains to be seen whether the initially successful negotiations between the north and Washington will progress, after Pyongyang called on Washington to make a stronger effort to build confidence and assure its security before it gives up its nuclear weapons.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

soon be entitled to&nbspbereavement leave in New Zealand.A bill, which also covers stillbirths and would legislate for three days’ paid bereavement leave, is to be considered by the country’s parliament.Ginny Anderson, the Labour MP who sponsored the bill, said miscarriage remained a “taboo subject” in the country.She argued paid leave to grieve for the loss of a baby would bring the issue into the public sphere.New Zealanders are currently entitled to bereavement leave after losing a family member or child but this fails to include the loss of a child who is not born alive.Woman tweets about being asked about children after miscarriagesMother launches Instagram account to end silence around miscarriageThe bereavement provisions of the Holidays Act 2003 are currently ambiguous in how they apply to miscarriage.A petition – which has already amassed over 3,700 signatures – in favour of the bill, says it would remove this uncertainty “by making it clear that the unplanned death of a foetus constitutes grounds for bereavement leave for the mother and her partner or spouse.”Kathryn van Beek, who had a miscarriage two years ago and started the petition, said: “Everyone reeling from story: Created with Sketch.A boy was slightly hurt after leaping off a balcony in fear, but no injuries are blamed directly on the quakesClick to followThe Independent OnlineEmergency service personnel arrive in Montecilfone after a 5.1-magnitude earthquake struck the regionAt least nine earthquakes have rocked southern Italy in two hours, prompting frightened residents to sleep outdoors.Italy's national seismology agency INGV says the strongest quake measured 5.1 and struck at 8:19 p.m. Thursday. That jolt was followed in rapid succession by eight more tremors, with the strongest measuring at 4.4.The epicentre of the quakes was Montecilfone, a small town in Campobasso province in the south-central region of Molise.Civil protection officials say a boy was slightly hurt after leaping off a balcony in fear, but no injuries are blamed directly on the quakes. Molise Gov. Donato Toma says some buildings suffered cracks but no major damage occurred.The biggest jolt was felt in much of Italy's south, including in Rome and Naples.The mayor of Montecilfone, the city near the epicentre of the largest quake, said people were scared but there was only minor damage.Some old walls that were already in bad shape have collapsed, but there's no major damage, Franco Pallotta said on SkyTG24.People are alarmed. Thank God, I have no news of injuries.The fire department confirmed that there had been no rescue calls from the area near the epicentre, noting that only slight damage to some buildings had been spotted.The Molise region's governor also said that only minor damage had been reported.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Are you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: hajj 2018 when date mecca muslim islam pilgrimage what need know
story: Created with Sketch.Two million Muslims journey to holy city from across the world every year as act of devotionClick to followThe Independent OnlineHajj 2018: When is the annual pilgrimage to Mecca? Everything you need to knowThe Hajj, the five-day annual pilgrimage&nbspundertaken by Muslims to the holy city of Mecca, will take place this weekend.The journey to Saudi Arabia results in the world's largest single gathering of people and is this year scheduled to begin on the evening of Sunday 19 August and ends on Friday 24 August.Here's everything you need to know.One of the Five Pillars of Islam, the Hajj is a sacred duty every Muslim must undertake at least once in their lifetime (unless they are prevented from doing so by ill health or financial hardship).The Quran&nbsptraces its origins to the story of Abraham, ordered by Allah to leave his wife Hajara and infant son Ishmael in the desert of ancient Mecca as an act of faith. Hajara searched frantically for water, passing between the hills of Safa and Marwah&nbspseven times, but found none, only for a fresh spring to burst from the ground beneath the child's foot.Abraham constructed the Kaaba on the spot, the black stone cuboid at the the centre of what became the Great Mosque, around which worshippers walk counter-clockwise seven times in solemn contemplation of their faith as part of the Tawaf.The Prophet Muhammad later marched from Medina to Mecca, his own birthplace,&nbspto rid the Kaaba&nbspof pagan idols in 632, reconsecrating it in honour of Allah.The pilgrimage in homage to the miracle and its legend today serves to unite Muslims and remind all followers of Islam that they are&nbspequal in the eyes of god.As such, pilgrims strip themselves of the material trappings of wealth and status and wear the plain white seamless robes of Ihram&nbspto indicate their spiritual state.In addition to circling the Kaaba, pilgrims say two Rakaat prayers at the Place of Abraham, re-enact Hajarah's hunt for water between&nbspSafa&nbspand Marwah, drink from the Zamzam&nbspWell, stand vigil at Mount Arafat and on the plains of Muzdalifa&nbspand cast stones at three pillars, a symbolic act&nbsprepresenting evil being driven from the hearts of men.The Hajj takes place between the eighth and&nbsp13th&nbspday of&nbspDhu&nbspal-Hijjah, the date of which alters every year by the Gregorian calendar because the Islamic lunar calendar is 11 days shorter.Eid&nbspal-Adha&nbspalso falls on the&nbsp10th&nbspday of the month. This is a Festival of Sacrifice in honour of Abraham's willingness to sacrifice Ishmael at Allah's request, a supreme act of faith, which he was prevented from having to carry out by the deity providing him with a goat to slaughter in his son's stead.Today, the same animal is sacrificed in memory of the story. It is cut into thirds: one portion is given to the impoverished, another to friends and relatives and the last retained&nbspand eaten by the family.Is the Hajj safe?Two million pilgrims are expected to take part this year, thousands of whom are embarking from the UK.While the occasion is a holy one, overcrowding led to a fatal stampede in 2015&nbspwhich killed over 2,000 pilgrims and Hajj fraudsters attempting to con visitors remain a real problem.“Some will arrive in Saudi Arabia to discover the accommodation they booked does not exist while others will find that their whole trip is in fact a scam set up by illegitimate travel operators that have disappeared with thousands of pounds of their money,”&nbspthe politan Police have warned.Advice on staying safe includes making sure&nbspyou travel with a reputable tour operator who is ATOL-protected and part of a recognised trade association such as ABTA. story: Created with Sketch.Crossbencher Fraser Anning widely condemned for his isive remarksClick to followIndy PoliticsAn Australian politician has provoked outrage after using the term “final solution” in an incendiary&nbspspeech about immigration, in which he called for a plebiscite asking voters whether they want to stop&nbspMuslims and those “from the third world” from entering the country.Queensland senator Fraser Anning’s provocative maiden speech called for an immigration program that favours “European Christian” values, claiming it would protect Australia from potential terror attacks.We as a nation are entitled to insist that those who are allowed to come here predominantly reflect the historic European-Christian composition of Australian society, the Katter’s Australian Party upper house MP said.Trump isn’t the only one whose immigration policy is doomed to failLaura Ingraham defends her immigration comments, disavows David DukeIf Trump got his way, Melania's parents would be illegal immigrantsMr Anning, who replaced Malcolm Roberts in the Senate back in June, called for “a plebiscite to allow the Australian people to decide whether they want wholesale non-English speaking immigrants from the third world, and particularly whether they want any Muslims”.“The majority of Muslims in Australia of working age do not work and exist on welfare. title: pampered pets treatment for fleas on my cat
story: Issues can be found with cats who have fleas due to forgetting to apply a product  (Image:  )A - There are many licensed insecticides available including collars, tablets, spot-ons and sprays, and if used properly, all are safe and effective.Your vet will explain how to apply them and how often.This is important because problems are often caused by forgetting to apply a product or not doing so properly.Failure to read the label is a major cause of insecticide poisoning in cats too.                Pampered pets: Why is one of my kittens trying to nurse on the other?The most common of these is with the insecticide permethrin, an ingredient in sprays and spot-ons that is clearly labelled for dogs only. This is very toxic to cats as their livers cannot deal with permethrin. Signs of intoxication are convulsions, hyperexcitability and seizures that come on suddenly, requiring emergency treatment, so use cat-only products from your vet.&nbspDavid Grant MBE was a vet at the RSPCA Harmsworth Hospital for Animals. Brexit stalemate EXPLODES as Leavers TURN on May                Boris Johnson set for Tory conference COMEBACK to demand FULL BREXIT&ldquoThis is part of our preparatory work that has been underway for the past two years.It was revealed in July that Theresa May was also preparing to publish over 70 technical notifications for businesses and iniduals, outlining how they could prepare for the UK setting out today that over August and September we&rsquore going to be releasing a number of technical notifications to set out what citizens and business need to do in the event of a title: meghan markle pregnant royal baby sign hair fashion clothes
story: In the past, the former actress has admitted using semi-permeant straightening treatments for her hair.Speaking in 2011, she said: &ldquoMy mum is black and my dad is Dutch and Irish, so the texture of my hair is densely curly.&ldquoI&rsquove been getting Brazilian blowouts for a couple of years.However, according to Myka Meier, who runs the Plaza Hotel's Duchess Effect etiquette courses, these beauty treatments could provide a very public indiction when she may be expecting.Ms Meier told the Sun&rsquos Fabulous magazine the chemicals involved in these treatments mean they might have to be avoided in pregnancy.                Meghan will 'NOT' talk to father until he contacts in &lsquoRESPECTFUL' way                Meghan and Kate wear THIS secret item to stop their dresses 'FLYING...She said of the Duchess: &ldquoThe one thing that might be interesting is her hair.&ldquoWe don&rsquot know what she does now, but it is likely she uses a keratin or a Brazilian treatment to straighten it.&ldquoAs soon as she gets pregnant she will no longer be able to use those same products which could be very interesting.&ldquoI use the same products and have very curly, frizzy hair and when I got pregnant I had to stop using all of those.Instead, the expert thinks Meghan may wear her hair up, rather than long and loose as we are accustomed to seeing.Ms Meier continued: &ldquoI think we&rsquoll see her wearing more of a bun when that happens, which could be a tell tale sign she is pregnant as she&rsquoll no longer be able to use those stringent chemicals that are often used or that beautiful glossy look.Meghan Markle's hair could change if she falls pregnant (Image:  )The best pictures of Meghan Markle as she celebrates her 37th birthday.                    PA1 of 45The best pictures of the Duchess of Sussex as celebrates her 37th birthdayHowever, the etiquette coach thinks we may have to wait a little longer than we&rsquore used to to find out about any Royal baby from the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.She said: &ldquoWith the Duchess of Cambridge, she was forced to tell everyone she was expecting because of hospitalisations.&ldquoHowever, with the Duchess of Sussex, hopefully that is not the case and she doesn&rsquot suffer with any sickness and she might try to hide her pregnancy a little longer and give herself privacy.&ldquoShe&rsquos already known to wear loose clothing so I think it&rsquos not like she&rsquoll go from tight clothing to very loose.One doctor agreed with Ms Meier&rsquos predictions, and suggested keratin hair treatments are avoided in pregnancy.Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patient.info, said: &ldquoLots of mums worry whether beauty treatments as well as medicines are safe when they&rsquore pregnant.&ldquoHair treatments obviously aren&rsquot taken internally like tablets but small amounts can be absorbed through the scalp and if there are fumes you can breathe them in.&ldquoThere isn&rsquot enough research to say for certain whether keratin treatments are safe, so doctors will usually suggest to be careful.She explained there is one ingredient which could be particularly dangerous: &ldquoThe exception is keratin treatments containing formaldehyde - and there have been concerns that at high levels, this can cause birth defects.&ldquoSo I recommend that women absolutely avoid any keratin product which might contain formaldehyde.Chemical hair straightening treatments last around four months each time, and can cost anything between &pound100 and &pound350.

title: Brexit news Femi Oluwole EU withdrawal no deal UK citizens right second referendum
story: Anti-Brexit campaigner Femi Oluwole suggested 1.4 million British citizens living abroad would lose the right to stay in the European Union without a deal.Mr Oluwole suggested that failing to secure an agreement with the bloc would strip expats of their right to live in any EU member state.But talkRADIO&nbsphost Julia Hartley-Brewer called him out, saying: No, it doesn&rsquot. That&rsquos a load of nonsense.Why on Earth would that happen? I bet my house on it.                Hunt tells EU countries not to follow UK who face 'difficult period'                RBS could move BILLIONS abroad over hard Brexit fears despite TAXPA...Ms Hartley-Brewer, who also said she would be perfectly happy with a no deal, was backed by the Institute of Economic Affairs boss Mark Littlewood.Mr Littlewood listened to Mr Oluwole's claims, visibly shaking his head, before adding: We are not going to have 1.4 million people evacuated.The anti-Brexit campaigner hit back saying that both Brexiteers were in a very privileged condition to have no fear about a no deal Brexit.Mr Oluwole said: It&rsquos a very, very privileged condition being able to say that no deal is acceptable.Brexit news: Hartley-Brewer branded as nonsensical Oluwele's claims about Brexit (Image: TALKRADIO)No deal means the 1.4 million British people who are living on the other side of the Channel would have no right to live in their own home.He also suggested people arguing against a second Brexit referendum are to be considered undemocratic, insisting British voters should have a say on the final deal agreed on with Brussels.Mr Oluwele continued: One could just as strongly argue that the democratic thing to do is for people to have a say.One of the major arguments behind Brexit in the first place was &lsquowe never signed up to this.&rsquo &lsquoWe never signed up to this, we signed up to a simple trade agreement in 1974 and it became something different.&rsquoRight now we have an opportunity that to have a say on what our new relationship with the EU is going to be. I think it&rsquos undemocratic to argue we shouldn&rsquot get one.Tory frontbencher Alistair Burt, who backed Remain at the EU referendum, launched a survey on his constituency website seeking local views on the possibility of a re-run of the historic vote.Mr Burt said he wanted to gauge opinion in his North East Bedfordshire constituency after a number of residents had voiced anger and concern about the progress with the country's withdrawal from the bloc.But Eurosceptic Tory MPs accused him of breaching government policy given Theresa May's repeated rejection of demands for a second EU referendum.Tory MP and Leave campaigner Andrew Bridgen said: Alistair Burt is an arch-Europhile. I hope this is not an indication of the way Government policy is heading.We haven't yet implemented the will of the people from the first referendum.I am not finding anyone in North West Leicestershire asking me for a second referendum.

title: Brexit news Guy Verhofstadt EU citizen Settled Status UK Home Office plan alphabetical
story: Guy Verhofstadt brands UK plan to register EU citizens alphabetically 'budget airline' standard  (Image: )Responding to reports, the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit negotiator suggested Westminster should work on a better solution and &ldquonot one that a budget airline would be proud of.The Home Office may have to register up to 3.6 million EU citizens for &ldquosettled status before Britain quits the EU on March 29 2019.Despite the system being due for a &ldquophased rollout toward the end of 2018, Home Office officials are still pondering how would be most efficient and politically acceptable to carry out the Brexit promise to respect the EU citizens wanting to remain in Britain.A number of methods are being considered, including registering EU applicants sector by sector or by geographical region. However, both plans risk backlash from those left at the back of the queue, which will feature at least three million names.Home Office officials believe registering EU citizens alphabetically could be the least politically sensitive out of the three proposals put forward, according to Business Insider.According to the plans, caseworkers would process applicants in &ldquobite-sized chunks in alphabetical order based on the first letter of their name.Mr Verhofstadt, chairman of the European Parliament&rsquos Brexit Steering Group, believes Britain&rsquos plan only creates further uncertainty for EU citizens.He said: &ldquoReports that the UK Home Office is considering registering EU citizen's alphabetically are deeply troubling.                Hunt tells EU countries not to follow UK who face 'difficult period'                Varadkar's EU spokesman warns no-deal will plunge UK into CHAOS&ldquoClearly, this would create confusion and add to uncertainty.&ldquoWe need a simple, efficient and fair process, not one that a budget airline would be proud of.The influential Belgian MEP&rsquos Steering Group also issued a statement urging Britain to reconsider the plans.It reads: &ldquoWe believe such an approach would be complicated, arbitrary and could create unnecessary confusion and uncertainty for millions of EU citizens already living in limbo.Guy Verhofstadt and Home Secretary Sajid Javid have been negotiating the UK's registration system (Image: )&ldquoThose at the end of the alphabet may not get their status confirmed until the end of 2020 or later, which would be intolerable and contrary to the spirit of the assurances we have previously received.We repeat our belief that the U.K.'s registration scheme must be simple, fair, user-friendly, free and provide certainty for EU citizens.The EU Parliament's Brexit committee has also urged EU countries to offer more certainty to Britons hoping to remain on the Continent after March 2019.

title: Brexit news update EU UK MI6 bug Chequers deal Theresa May
story: Speaking on Sky News, the former Trade and Industry Secretary claimed he was not surprised to hear Brussels is worried the UK has been trying to hack its Brexit documents following reports coming from a&nbsptop European source.&nbspThe Conservative peer argued it should be naturally assumed both sides are trying to obtain information from the other side on internal conversations about the Brexit negotiations.&nbspHe revealed his mobile phone was coded by British secret services when he was a minister to prevent French secret services bugging his phone while he was there on holiday.He said: &ldquoI think we should assume both sides will try and bug the other side.                Is MI6 BUGGING the Brexit talks? EU officials raise concerns                 Brexit news: EU kept Chequers demolition documents SECRET to save May&ldquoCertainly, when I was Trade and Industry Minister British security services installed coding equipment on my phone here in France, so that if I was over here they assumed it would be bugged by the French - maybe it wasn&rsquot, maybe it was - but they wanted my conversations to be secure if I was phoning back to Downing Street or Whitehall.&ldquoAs I said, we should probably assume that the secret services of both sides are trying to hack.&ldquoIn this case I think it&rsquos overwhelmingly likely that the information which apparently reached the British Government came from a leak from someone within the EU who thought we ought to know about it.&ldquoAnd indeed the whole Cabinet ought to know about it.Brexit news: Lord Lilley claims UK should assume EU is trying to hack its documents (Image: SKY&bull)&ldquoThe real scandal is not in the question whether or not there was any bugging, but why the Cabinet, when it was assembled at Chequers, wasn&rsquot told about this reaction by the EU to the proposals which they were being asked to consider.Lord Lilley's comments come as a top European source told The Daily  that the EU&rsquos Brexit negotiating team fear they are being bugged, with the UK team getting hold of secret files &ldquowithin hours of them being presented to EU officials.According to the source, concerns were raised at a meeting of the European Council, which includes the leaders of all EU member states as well as top Brussels officials, on July 12.Sabine Wayard, the European Commission&rsquos Deputy Chief Negotiator, reportedly told the meeting that &ldquoit could not be excluded that their meetings were being bugged by the Brits.European fears developed after the UK team got told of a secret presentation shortly after it was distributed on July 5.This came at a politically explosive time, taking place just one day before Theresa May&rsquos contentious Chequers Cabinet meeting during which the UK&rsquos proposed Brexit position was agreed.The European Commission documents are believed to have been kept top secret because they threatened to dismantle Theresa May&rsquos controversial Chequers plan before its release and risk toppling her fragile minority government in Westminster.However according to the allegations within hours the UK team had got hold of the documents, and lobbied at the &ldquohighest level to prevent their publication.The slides were not formally circulated to the other 27 EU member states, according to the Daily  report.The European Commission declined to comment.

title: Brexit news latest UK EU vote no deal referendum European Union Iain Duncan Smith
story: The former Tory leader demanded that the European Union stop putting politics in the way of a &ldquoreasonable free trade deal.Speaking on Bloomberg News, Mr Duncan Smith insisted the financial markets should stop constantly panicking over&nbspBrexit&nbspbefore launching into a furious rant at the Brussels bloc.Mr Duncan Smith said: &ldquoThe markets themselves have got to be a bit more responsible about constantly panicking, jumping and being jittery about these things and just take a longer look at this.&ldquoIt will eventually get settled. We are leaving and I think the prospects are remarkable. We are a global trading nation and I think we have got to make the most of that.When asked if the markets will be impacted by the type of deal Britain has, Mr Duncan Smith said: &ldquoYes but it is also about the EU being sensible and not putting politics in the way of what is a reasonable and frictionless deal.                Brexit news: Verhofstadt blasts UK's new plan to register EU citizens                 Tory peer REVEALS secret service coded his phone to stop French bug&ldquoThat&rsquos what they should be aiming for.The Tory Brexiteer then said he is &ldquonot in favour of the Chequers deal but said Britons are &ldquoworried about what the EU will &ldquodemand to ever get half of that deal.He said: &ldquoMy point is I would have gone for the original proposal which was to have a free trade deal done on the basis of the best of the free trade deals that they have done already with some extra bits and pieces like the financial services area for the UK and make it as simple as possible.&ldquoI think we may even be at that point by October and November.Brexit news: IDS said the European Union should be sensible in negotiation (Image: &bullBloomberg)Prime Minister Theresa May's Chequers proposal would see Britain maintain close commercial ties with the EU through a free trade area managed by a common rulebook.Mrs May&rsquos Brexit proposal has sparked fury among Conservative Party members and let to the resignation of Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.A faction of Brexiteer dissidents, spearheaded by Jacob Rees-Mogg, is working to create an &ldquoalternative view to the Government&rsquos White Paper.Still in the development stages, the policy paper they aim to publish is understood to follow a Canadian-style free trade agreement, but only if the EU compromises on demands over the Irish border.

story: The former Tory leader also hit out at the general financial market consensus for &ldquopanicking about Brexit.Speaking on Bloomberg News, Mr Duncan Smith said: &ldquoWith respect to the markets, they have been forecasting incorrectly for a long time.The Brexiteer MP warned that if Britain were to go on what the financial markets forecast for the future then the country would have &ldquomade an awful lot of mistakes already anyway.He added: &ldquoThe idea that the UK was going to have a declining level of growth is actually not the case.                Tory peer REVEALS secret service coded his phone to stop French bug                Iain Duncan Smith explains exactly what the Brussels bloc SHOULD do&ldquoEven the Governor of the Bank of England got it wrong the other day when he said the UK is at the bottom of the G7. It&rsquos not.&ldquoMy point is the more you talk about these things as though they are negatives &ndash the answer is the UK economy is more robust than people give it credit for.&ldquoThese constant forecasts about this downgrading of the UK economy when they keep getting beaten by the fact the UK economy grows. Again, the high street sales are infinitely better than&nbspthey&nbspwere forecast to be.&ldquoI&rsquom not over-cooking it. I&rsquom simply saying the markets themselves have got to be a bit more responsible about constantly panicking, jumping and being jittery about these things and just take a longer look at this.&ldquoIt will eventually get settled. We are leaving and I think the prospects are remarkable. We are a global trading nation and I think we have got to make the most of that.The former Tory leader also warned the EU should &ldquobe sensible in Brexit negotiations or risk disrupting the already &ldquojittery markets.Mr Duncan Smith hit out at the EU and said: &ldquoYes but it is also about the EU being sensible and not putting politics in the way of what is a reasonable and frictionless deal.&ldquoThat&rsquos what they should be aiming for.The Tory Brexiteer then said he is &ldquonot in favour of the Chequers deal but said Britons are &ldquoworried about what the EU will &ldquodemand to ever get half of that deal.Brexit news: IDS says Mark Carney got it wrong in his comments on Brexit (Image: &bullBloomberg)Mr Carney claimed in August that the chances of a Brexit no deal are &ldquouncomfortably high and warned political &ldquoparties should do all they can to avoid it during a Brexit-bashing interview on the Today programme.The Bank of England boss also said a no-deal Brexit was &ldquohighly undesirable as he warned both the UK and EU to avoid it. The pound weakened below $1.30 as he spoke and was down 0.3 percent at $1.2982 as of 8:56am.Mr Carney said: &ldquoI think the possibility of a no-deal is uncomfortably high at this point.He added: We have been planning for very difficult circumstances and the banks are ready.When you adjust for the stimulus we've given, the stimulus the Government has given and the strength of the global economy, it's about 1.75 or two percentage points lower than it otherwise would have been - that's our projection on projection estimate. That is a big difference.So we've gone from the fastest to the slowest growing in the G7, we've had a big shift in sterling - 17 percentage points - and we went through the latter half of 2016 and last year with a real pay squeeze on British households, which we're just getting out of.

title: scotland news SNP education teachers staff john swinney
story: Mr Swinney was also challenged over his ability to tackle the situation as radio phone-in callers lambasted a string of failures.The gruelling broadcast followed the threat of a mass boycott over the SNP&rsquos controversial primary one tests.His government&rsquos record came under further attack this week after it emerged more than 200 schools have vacancies for teachers and classroom support staff as pupils return from the summer holiday.Mr Swinney is already facing a possible national teachers&rsquo strike in the autumn in a separate dispute over pay.                SNP told to AXE school tests for FIVE-YEAR-OLDSThe Cabinet minister has said he will review how the tests are delivered to the youngest children has but ruled out scrapping them.Today he conceded there were &ldquomixed opinions about the new standardised assessments but argued they help schools quickly identify &ldquoweaknesses and challenges.Mr Swinney also insisted Scotland there is no &ldquocrisis in morale as he appeared on the BBC Radio Scotland phone-in with Stephen Jardine.But he did concede there were &ldquochallenges in the profession as he was grilled by one retiring professional.The woman, identified as Susan, said she had been a teacher for 39 years, 21 of them as a head teacher.John Swinney was under fire over the current crisis with Scottish education  (Image: )There was a threat of a mass boycott of SNP primary tests (Image: )She told Mr Swinney his government&rsquos reforms were &ldquonot addressing the workload pressures teachers are under.She said the working-time agreement was &ldquoalmost a joke, and said &ldquothere&rsquos no way teachers can do their work in the contracted hours.Susan added: &ldquoThe number of teachers who are leaving - haemorrhaging out of the profession - I would like to know how many probationer teachers carry on and how many years they go into the profession.&ldquoYou have a real crisis in recruitment and retention and I don&rsquot hear anything there that you&rsquove said this morning that would convince me that you have got a handle on this.Mr Swinney said he accepted that &ldquoteaching life is a very busy and demanding life, but said he had engaged with teachers and professional groups to improve matters.He pointed to measures, including bursaries, to attract new teachers, adding: &ldquoI don&rsquot think we have a crisis in morale.&ldquoOf course there will be tough bits in all these discussions, but there are great bits as well.&ldquoThere are tough challenges, but also a lot of things to celebrate in Scottish education.                Sturgeon REFUSES to climbdown on state  scheme                 SNP accused of blocking Prince Charles papers in secrecy rowBut Susan said: &ldquoI just feel it&rsquos &lsquocrisis, what crisis&rsquo, and he&rsquos not listening at all.Lesley, a grandmother from the Borders, told Mr Swinney that pupils were let down by a lack of teachers, and a failing exam system.She said: &ldquoI don&rsquot think the system is working and it is punishing children very badly.&ldquoIt is robbing them of their confidence, it is robbing them of their ability and it is robbing them of what should be a good life for them.One parent, who was not named, asked Mr Swinney what he planned to do about the ongoing recruitment crisis in schools.She claimed that her children&rsquos school had been &ldquodown a chemistry teacher for five years and said her son &ldquowas taught physics last year by a man who could barely read or write English in North Lanarkshire.Following the broadcast Scottish Labour&rsquos education spokesman Iain Gray said: &ldquoJohn Swinney shows no sign of listening to parents or teachers.&ldquoThe message was loud and clear that he should drop his testing of four and five year olds in P1, and if he wants to fix the teacher recruitment crisis he has to do something about teachers&rsquo pay and workload.Mr Swinney has come under increasing pressure to scrap testing for the youngest pupils after campaign group Upstart Scotland urged parents to withdraw their children.The Lib Dems have also claimed that the Scottish Government deceived parents about their right to withdraw their children if they choose.The government insists parents have &ldquono statutory right of opt out, but schools have &ldquodiscretion to decide whether pupils should take part.

title: a level results highest grades since 2012 boys better than girls
story: The top two grades were awarded to 26.4 per cent of UK entries.Split by gender the figures were 26.6 per cent for boys and 26.2 per cent for girls.The overall pass rate fell slightly to 96.7 per cent.It was also revealed fewer students have been accepted into universities this year.                Embarrassed Blair son asked about tuition fees during A levels debate                German A Level EXTINCTION? Chinese MORE POPULAR with UK studentsThe latest figures come in the wake of a major exams overhaul, with 24 A-level subjects now reformed as part of sweeping changes.Grades were also awarded for the first time this summer for several new-look A-levels &ndash in languages, geography, dance, drama and theatre, music, PE and religious studies.Education Secretary Damian Hinds said the redesign of A-levels would make them &ldquomore appropriate and better at preparing young people for moving on to the next stage.He said: &ldquoHaving exams at the end of two years means it is possible to consider the subject as a whole.Students celebrate their A Level results at Brighton College in East Sussex (Image: PA)Natasha Vincent, daughter of  presenter Katie Derham, celebrates her A Level results at Brighton Col (Image: PA)&ldquoWe can bring in all the different parts of it, to synthesise the different aspects of the subject in a way that is a little closer to undergraduate study.It is the second year in a row the A*-A pass rate has risen.One in 12 entries scored an A* grade this year, down 0.3 percentage points on last year, according to statistics published by the Joint Council for Qualifications.This is the lowest it has been since 2013. The overall A*-E pass rate has also fallen 0.3 percentage points to 97.6 per cent, the lowest level since 2010.For the second year running boys continued to outperform girls at the highest grades, the figures showed.Michael Turner, Joint Council for Qualifications director general, played down any talk of exams getting too easy.                How the Royal Family did in their A Levels - you&rsquoll be surprised                A Level Results: Jeremy Clarkson inspires students with low gradesBest friends Meera Trivedi (L) and Iram Farooqui (R) will both read history at Oxford  (Image: SWNS)He said: &ldquoStudents and teachers should be congratulated.&ldquoThey can be confident in their grades, knowing they have been achieved in a world-class system that is robust, challenging and fair.Yesterday&rsquos results also showed that Stem (science, technology, engineering and maths) subjects were continuing to rise in popularity.More than a third (36.2 per cent) of all A-level entries were in these subjects, up from 34.5 per cent last year, and 28 per cent in 2009.Boys were still more likely to study a Stem subject than girls, but the balance is shifting, the JCQ said.More girls take biology and chemistry than boys, while more boys take maths and physics.Students celebrate despite rain at Peter Symonds College, Winchester (Image: PA)But the data also showed girls were closing in on boys in this area, with a 3.1 per cent increase in maths entries from female students (boys&rsquo entries have risen 2.1 per cent) and a 6.9 per cent rise in physics (2.4 per cent for boys).Maths is still the most popular A-level with 2,383 more entries this year than last year.There were more entries for A-level Chinese this year than for A-level German.There were 3,334 entries for Chinese, up 8.6 per cent on last year. Some 3,058 students took German, down 16.5 per cent.Suzanne O&rsquoFarrell, from the Association of School and College Leaders, said: &ldquoWe&rsquore seeing German moving into extinction. It is in severe decline.French remains the most popular language with 8,713 entries, down eight per cent.

title: UK weather forecast cold front UK gale force winds cold temperatures met office forecast
story: UK weather forecast: Britons will experience wet and windy weather this weekend  (Image: WXCHARTS)In a sign the seasons are changing, Britons will experience wet and windy weather this weekend as temperatures nose-e and thick cloud cover dominates the outlook.The conditions will temporarily bring summer to a premature end, as gusts and rainfall sweep across the country.Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said: &ldquoIt will be a fine day for most in the south, but increasingly cloud and dampness pushes in during Friday across north western areas.He revealed the cloud and rainfall that had dominated the picture across the south east of England on Thursday would clear away quite quickly as we headed into Friday.                UK tsunami WARNING: Devon and Cornwall hit with alert - &lsquoworst-case...But the clearing of the cloud in the south east would, Mr McGivern explained, bring clearer skies and a cold front, which would usher in cooler air across the country.He said: &ldquoA few showers will continue across central and western Scotland and north west England and for Northern Ireland, we will see thicker cloud returning, with some rain for the west of the province.The weather expert ulged Friday would have a clear and bright start, but the cloudless skies would bring a fresh feel.He said: &ldquoCentral and eastern Scotland, much of England and Wales, will see sunny spells.UK weather forecast: wet and damp conditions are set to dominate the picture over the weekend (Image: )However, he cautioned quite quickly clouds would thicken across central and western Scotland, north west England, north Wales and Northern Ireland.He said: &ldquoAfter a sunny morning, the south and east will tend to cloud over during the afternoon.&ldquoRain sets in during the afternoon the wind picks up too so it is going to feel cool.But the meteorologist revealed, on a brighter note, in the far south east - which would cling on to some sunny spells - temperatures could reach as high as 23 degrees.UK weather forecast: festival-goers endure the wet weather at Watergate Bay (Image:  )UK weather forecast: a Wolverhampton Wanderers fan watches the rain at a match against Everton FC  (Image:  )                UK weather forecast map: When will tropical storm Ernesto PUMMEL UK?                Met Office forecast: 12-HOUR downpour to hit UK - Britain set for w...He said: &ldquoFurther north we have the thicker cloud pushing through and we have the winds picking up during Friday.Mr McGivern also warned of gales around north western coasts, which would transfer away towards the north of the mainland of Scotland and the northern isles.But northern parts of the UK would stay windy over Friday night and overall, he advised, the south would stay mostly dry and cloudy.The Met Office expert said: &ldquoAnd the legacy of this frontal system through central areas joins up to the next weather front in the northern Atlantic, which provides an awful lot of cloud cover through southern Scotland, northern England and parts of Northern Ireland as well.Mr McGivern explained the extensive cloud cover would result in a damp start to the weekend.However, conditions would be brighter further south and further north, he predicted.He said: &ldquoFurther south, winds will be much lighter, with a fair amount of warm sunshine, though patchy rain may affect western hills.Mr McGivern confirmed the gales in the far north of the UK would ease through the day, but that it would be a blustery day, peppered with showers.He said: &ldquoAnd then more rain moves through later on Saturday in northern districts.

story: The study, written by Dr Robert Hanck&eacute of the London School of Economics in partnership with derivatives trading company IG, looked at what would happen were Germany to decide to quit the single European currency and go it alone one more &ndash with potentially dire economic consequences.It states: &ldquoAs the strongest economy in the eurozone, Germany is the only country that can credibly leave the euro.&ldquoSome German citizens and politicians see themselves as 'victims&rsquo of the euro, feeling that it forces them to prop up countries with weaker economies.&ldquoIf that feeling grows, a majority of citizens could vote in favour of a new deutschmark if given the choice.                Economist warns Macron's plan last chance to save 'unsustainable' EU                Germany MUST pay for Brexit EU budget shortfall, claims expertThe research points out that Germany is the &ldquoeconomically dominant country in the euro area, accounting for&nbsproughly 27 percent of the eurozone&rsquos total GDP.In addition, it has a general government budget surplus of approximately 1.5 million.The report suggestions that a move to create a new German national currency would have &ldquodramatic regional consequences and would very likely to opposed by other 18 member-states of the EU who have adopted the euro as their currency.The report suggests: &ldquoGermany&rsquos departure from the eurozone would likely lead to the collapse of the currency and conceivably even the European Union as a whole.The eurozone would be threatened by a relaunched Deutschmark (Image: )A total of 19 countries are in the euro area (Image: Wikipedia)Most of the northern economies would probably turn their backs on economic and monetary union to join a new deutchsmark bloc, the report argues.The euro&rsquos collapse would have a serious impact on the political consensus which has dominated Europe since World War 2.Neither would Germany be immune from the fallout, because the launch of a new deutschmark, which would attract huge levels of investment with the result that other currencies operating in the now likely defunct eurozone would be depreciated.As a result, this could have a knock-on effect on Germany&rsquos exports, triggering a deep economic recession in the country similar to that witnessed in the early 1990s.                Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling &lsquounlikely to recover losses&rsquo                 'EU is TERRIFIED' Italy says Brussels RUNNING SCARED of populist up...Emmanuel Macron, pictured with Germany chancellor Angela Merkel, wants eurozone reform (Image: )Dr Hanck&eacute, Associate Professor of Political Economy at the LSE said: &ldquoThe political will among European elites to keep the euro intact is, as we have seen since the Greek bailouts, very strong.&ldquoStrong enough to bear the costs of the single currency &ndash unless, that is, German voters and politicians begin to perceive these costs to be too lopsided.The warnings come on the same day Italian economist Ilaira Bifarini told Express French President Emmanuel Macron&rsquos plan to increase EU integration might be the bloc&rsquos only chance.He said: &ldquoMacron&rsquos plan is the only solution for the European monetary union and the European Union as a whole to survive.&ldquoWe&rsquore facing a crossroads.&ldquoThe EU can either go towards more integration, more risk sharing, and also towards more cohesion of economic policies and not only those monetary, or there can&rsquot be anything other than an implosion of the euro system &ndash which is proving to be no longer sustainable.&ldquoSo the options are two. More integration or a breakup.Mr Macron wants to create a stand-alone eurozone budget and a new EU finance minister with the aim of strengthening economic and monetary union.For more details of various currency scenarios, click here

Was on the stairs and scrambled outside.Italy earthquake: A 5.2 magnitude tremor hit central Italy just days after a weaker 4.6 quake struck (Image: EPA)Footage posted on social media shows the moment ceiling lights in a house began to shake with the tremor.In another clip, people&nbspin the coastal town of Termoli can be seen gathering in a central square after the quake.Today&rsquos tremor is the second quake to hit the Molise region so far this week.On Tuesday, a 4.6 magnitude earthquake also struck near Montecilfone.Emergency services have rescued at least one woman in Montecilfone (Image: EPA)No damage was reported, but residents in the area reported feeling the earth move.In 2016, a major earthquake in central Italy claimed nearly 300 lives.The magnitude 6.2 tremor hit in the Accumoli area, some 75km southeast from the popular holiday city of Perugia.The historic town of Amatrice near the epicentre of the quake suffered severe damage as entire buildings collapsed under the violent shaking.
